name: Chapter 11: Edge Locations and Caching
description: Flashcards explaining how AWS uses edge locations and caching to reduce latency and improve content delivery with Amazon CloudFront.

cards.front: Why might a customer in China experience slow load times when content is hosted in Brazil?
cards.back: Because the data must travel a long physical distance from the origin server in Brazil, causing high latency and a poor user experience.
cards.example: A pizza shop in Brazil taking orders from China results in cold deliveries due to the distance—same with content hosted far from the user.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: The source server (e.g., EC2 or S3) that holds original application data or content.
The time delay between a user's request and the response from the server.

cards.front: How does AWS deliver content faster to users who are far from your origin server?
cards.back: By using Amazon CloudFront edge locations that cache content closer to users, reducing the distance data must travel.
cards.example: Setting up a pizza kiosk in Shanghai allows fast local delivery rather than shipping from Brazil. Edge locations do the same for AWS.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: A site used by CloudFront to cache content close to users.
AWS’s global content delivery network that distributes content via edge locations.

cards.front: What happens when a user repeatedly requests the same content through CloudFront?
cards.back: If the content is cached at the edge location, CloudFront serves it immediately from there, improving speed and reducing load on the origin server.
cards.example: A pizza kiosk keeps popular orders ready to serve fast—like cached content ready at an edge location for repeat user requests.
cards.mnemonic: Hot from the kiosk, not from the continent.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Introduction to Information Technology and AWS Cloud

glossary.definition: Temporary storage for frequently accessed data located at an edge location.
A system of distributed servers that deliver web content based on user location.
